data.title: Bob Hoskins dead at 71: Actor dies following battle with pneumonia
data.meta_description: The star was best known for his roles including Who Framed Roger Rabbit and Mona Lisa
data.text:
The actor Bob Hoskins has died at the age of 71, his agent has confirmed.

The star - best known for his roles in films including Who Framed Roger Rabbit, The Long Good Friday and Hook - had been battling pneumonia.

Hoskins was brought up in north London and was well-known for playing Cockney and East End gangster characters.

He was nominated for an Oscar and won a BAFTA and Golden Globe for his performance in the 1986 film Mona Lisa.

Follow our latest updates and tributes to Bob Hoskins here

He retired from screen work in 2012 after he was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

His family released a statement saying he died last night in hospital.

Hoskins' wife Linda and children Alex, Sarah, Rosa and Jack said: "We are devastated by the loss of our beloved Bob.

"Bob died peacefully at hospital last night surrounded by family, following a bout of pneumonia.

"We ask that you respect our privacy during this time and thank you for your messages of love and support."

In the early 60s, Hoskins hitchhiked across Europe and ended up working on a kibbutz in Israel.

On his return to Britain, he fell into acting when he went to an audition with a friend and was mistaken for someone reading for a role.

He started off in theatre but by the early 70s he was getting regular TV work in dramas such as Crown Court and Softly Softly.

Then came his breakthrough role as sheet music salesman Arthur Parker in Pennies From Heaven, followed by the movies The Long Good Friday in 1980 and Mona Lisa in 1986, for which he was Oscar nominated.

Hoskins went on to appear in a string of hits including Mermaids, with Cher, and director Oliver Stone's Nixon, in which he played FBI boss J. Edgar Hoover.

He was also in the romantic comedy Maid In Manhattan, with Jennifer Lopez and Ralph Fiennes.
